Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an attempt to legitimize censorship that occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Concerns about government overreach and control over what people can see, hear, or read.
The terms 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are ill-defined and subjective.
The legislation could lead to abuse of power and restrict freedom of speech.
Exclusion of media and government from the legislation is seen as problematic.
The legislation could suppress alternative or citizen media.
Existing laws and voluntary codes are deemed sufficient for handling misinformation.
Main Themes: Definition and identification of misinformation and disinformation
Notable Quotes: This proposed legislation appears to be an attempt to legitimise the censorship of Australians that the Government covertly carried out during the Covid drama.
Misinformation cannot be legislated against for the very reason it goes against freedom of speech.
If this legislation goes ahead, the media cannot be excluded.
To attempt to do so can only be classed as an abuse of power by the government or its agent.
